thread.title: China sends TROOPS to North Korea border after 'Kim kills protected brother'
thread.title_full: China sends TROOPS to North Korea border after 'Kim kills protected brother'

title: China sends TROOPS to North Korea border after 'Kim kills protected brother'

organizations.name: chinese foreign ministry  hong kong newspaper oriental daily news

text:
GETTY WARPATH: North Korea's Kim Jong-un, left, and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, right 
Kim Jong-nam, who was killed on Tuesday , had lived in China and some say he was being groomed to take over from his half brother. 
He'd advocated change and it was speculated that he could bring Chinese-style market reforms to his North Korean homeland. 
But with the exiled brother lying dead, that's impossible, and now Beijing is massing troops on Kim Jong-un's borders. 
GETTY FIRSTBORN: Kim Jong-nam with his dad, former North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il “We are very interested in the progress of the case” Chinese Foreign Ministry 
Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily News reported that China had deployed 1,000 additional troops in the frontier. 
Local residents have confirmed their arrival, though Beijing has not yet commented on the military movement. 
China and North Korea have long had cozy relations, with Pyongyang boasting that they're close as teeth and lips. 
But really there's tension between the two – Beijing is embarrassed by its neighbour, while North Korea envies China's wealth. Inside North Korea: The pictures Kim Jong-un doesn't want you to see Tuesday, 13th December 2016 Since 2008, photographer Eric Lafforgue ventured to North Korea six times. Thanks to digital memory cards, he was able to save photos that was forbidden to take inside the segregated state 1 / 62 Eric Lafforgue/Exclusivepix Medi Taking pictures in the DMZ is easy, but if you come too close to the soldiers, they stop you 
Defector Jang Jin-sung, who was once poet laureate of North Korea, said the last leader Kim Jong-il hated China above all other countries. 
In his memoir, Dear Leader, Mr Jang described how "China, more than anyone else, proved to be the thorn in his [Kim Jong-il's] side." 
He wrote: "The US could easily be cast as the embodiment of imperialism… China, however, was supposed to be a socialist nation… 
"[It was] forever tempting the isolated North Korean people with the fruits of reform and openness from over the border." 
Foreign ministry spokesman Geng Shuang admitted China was interested in the death of Kim Jong-nam on Wednesday. 
According to South Korea's Yonhap News Agency, he said his government was "paying attention to reports". 
"We are very interested in the progress of the case," Mr Shuang told reporters at his briefing. 
Two women and one man have been arrested over the death at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia. Related articles
